ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a comprehensive understanding of early Russian history.
Russian history
Learnt a tremendous amount of Russian history and how it has impacted modern Eastern Europe.
I gained a great survey of Russian history to the 19th century and the trends and patterns that characterized Russian state development.
I learned so much about Russia and the surrounding lands, which I feel gives me a much better foundation for understanding Eastern Europe in medieval times, and post-revolution Russia.

My knowledge of Russian history has definitely increased exponentially because of this course. Prof. Bushkovitch and Kostas did a great job of synthesizing centuries of information and I definitely gained a lot of insight into Russia through this course.
I learned a lot about early Russian history, which was very interesting in the context of recent geopolitical events like the war in Ukraine.
I learned a lot about Russian history during the period in question.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Readings were well structured and approachable, reasonable expectation of reading comprehension in section.
I think that it was an excellent course, Professor Bushkovitch is a great lecturer and Kostas was a very helpful and knowledgable TF.
Strengths are the course load, the grade is based on your midterm and final exam grade. Weaknesses is that lecturers were routinely quite boring.
Bushkovitch has a fantastic sense of humor, as did my TA. Lectures are interesting and lively - I can honestly say its the only course at Yale Ive genuinely woken up excited to go to.
The course is very straightforward and well taught. I would only have had a problem if I did not like lectures.
I found no weaknesses. I enjoyed the class size, lecture structure, and format of sections

The lectures are interesting but the readings are pretty long, and because we are tested on the readings specifically, it ends up being a bit stressful. But the course was interesting and the lectures had engaging themes!

Strengths: content was interesting, lectures were engaging, TA was great, grading was fair
Weaknesses: professor sometimes acted sneeringly dismissive toward people in the class. This was more amusing than annoying though
Strengths: Professor Bushkovitch, the exams Weaknesses: the readings in the first half of the course were pretty dense and dry

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I think this would be a very fun course for everyone interested in Russian History.
Yes if you want a chill history class.

This is by far and away my favorite course at Yale. The material is consistently fascinating and Bushkovitch is a veritable font of information. His lectures are very old school but his wisdom and humor always shines through.

I would! The course was well taught and Kostas Zivas was a great TF. Lectures were clear, interesting, and informative. You get what's on the tin, a great survey of Russian history from the 9th century to 1801.
I would definitely recommend be this course to anybody interested in Slavic studies or world history generally. I learned so much, even specifics, over such a broad period range.
Yes, it gives a lot of insight into Russia as a country and even gives you an interesting perspective on world/European politics. I really enjoyed it!

I would, but only if you're very interested in this time in history. I personally liked the class, but it might not be everyone's cup of tea. The lectures were engaging (although not at all interactive), the grading was fair, and the TA (Kostas) was great. But the professor doesn't always acts like he cares about the class, and can be sneeringly dismissive toward students. Like when he spent five minutes during the last class telling us that if we stress out about our future jobs in marketing the same way we stress out about our grades, we'll cause fractures in our families. Or about the final exam: "As long as you dont go to sleep or spend the next week stone-cold drunk or on drugs, you should be fine." Honestly I thought it was kind of entertaining, but I can see how it could grate on people.
Yes, if you would like to learn about Russian history and are interested in a history course without a paper. Professor Bushkovitch's fifty-minute lectures are informative and entertaining.

extras.title: HIST 290 01/RSEE 225 01 - Russia from the 9th C to 1801
